title: Why do lyrics in Japanese songs sung by female singers often use the male pronoun 'boku'? - Quora

response.answer_text: As you’ve implied, pronouns in Japanese are gendered and yes, “boku” is a pronoun primarily used by young males. There are a few possible explanations, the first of which is most likely: The “I” that’s referenced in the song, is not the female singer, but a different male. If you take a step back and think about English for a second, a sizable percentage of the 10s of thousands of English-language songs that contain the word “I” are not referencing the singer themselves. They might be speaking from a specific person’s voice or a generalized person’s voice. To take a random example, Bon Jovi’s “Livin’ On A Prayer”: Whoa, we're half way thereWhoa, livin' on a prayerTake my hand and we'll make it - I swearWhoa, livin' on a prayer Notice the “I swear” line. The “I” in question here is either Tommy (“who used to work on the docks”) or Gina (“who works the diner all day”) — neither of whom are Jon Bon Jovi himself.* Because Jon Bon Jovi is considered male, we imbue the “I” with maleness. If the song were covered by a female, the “I” would be imbued with femaleness. Needless to say, the pronoun doesn’t change because in English we don’t have gendered pronouns. In Japanese, on the other hand, the singer would get to choose. Does he/she want the “I” to be the voice of Tommy (male - Boku, Ore, etc), Gina (female - Atashi, etc) or gender neutral (Watashi, etc). This has nothing to do with the gender of the singer. In this scenario, their choice of “I” isn’t intended to be gender-bending, it is very literal. The “I” is male — therefore they use Boku. An offshoot example on the same theme is where the “I” is used in quotation. An example from Bob Dylan’s “Visions Of Johanna”: When the jelly-faced women all sneezeHear the one with the mustache say, "JeezeI can't find my knees." In translation, Bob Dylan or any male singer, would naturally use a feminine pronoun or a gender-neutral one where femininity is implied. And rightly so, the “I” isn’t him, it’s the woman with the mustache! The second possibility is that the “I” that’s referenced in the song, is intentionally masculine (or just being playful), even though it’s a female singer. She, for whatever reason, wants to reference herself in a masculine way. Imagine a strong female singing the song “I’ve Been Working On The Railroad”. She might gender it male as a show of strength. The third possibility is that the original song was “boku” and she just kept it that way. It could be just to preserve the original way, or for structural reasons. For example, “Boku” is two-syllables, “Ore” (another male pronoun) is also two-syllables, while “Atashi” and “Watashi” (female and neutral respectively) are three syllables. That can make swapping out a male with a female pronoun quite tricky.** It shouldn’t make you uncomfortable, though. As you get more exposure to Japanese language and culture, you’ll run into many examples of males (even tough and angry males) using what sounds like, or is feminine language. You’ll also begin to realize that there are many cultural examples of male and female gender-swapping (example: Kabuki is commonly all male, even the female roles, and Takarazuka is all-female, even the male roles). Best of luck with your Japanese studies and keep asking questions as you learn! *I’m aware that there is yet another interpretation of the song where Jon Bon Jovi is telling the story of Tommy and Gina to a yet unnamed person and the “I” in question is himself. **I guess they could go with the Hiroshima-style, two-syllabled, “Washi” pronoun if the song allowed for it :-)

Not sure if it's true but I've heard this was started by the song "Momen no Handkerchief (木綿のハンカチーフ)".   Its lyric uses a boy & girl dialogue, therefore it naturally has the first person singular pronoun for boy and girl. The song was commercially successful so much that I guess many songs tried to follow.
